result.execSummary:
The defendant Andrew S. Pray was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • 1st-Degree Intentional Homicide, a class A felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.01(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Pay restitution of $217.00 to Julia Buchberger.
Pay restitution of $1,313.40 to Elizabeth Bonnstetter-Kluck. 
Court grants the State 30 days for any further restitution request. 
Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge. 

25% of all moneys deposited into the defendants prison account shall be applied to the payment of fines, costs & restitution in this file.  If any fines, costs & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.
Pay costs including the DNA and Domestic Abuse Surcharge.

Eligible for Petitioning for Extended Supervision after serving 20 years.
Do not have any contact with the biological family of Christopher Bonnstetter unless they consent to such contact and the social worker allows.
If there is any wish for victim offender counseling, Court will admit that.
Comply with any assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Department of Corrections and their use of the COMPAS assessment.
Sign releases of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacies and/or treatment that Defendant receives, to the agent.
Provide DNA for testing.

**10/7/15:  The date upon which the defendant is eligible to petition for Extended Supervision after serving 20 years shall be established after the jail credit of 378 days has been applied.   The 378 days are to be included as part of the 20 year period.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Andrew S. Pray in court with attorney Nathan Tierney Otis. Defendant Andrew S. Pray in custody. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

1:31 PM Court calls case.

Matter is before the Court for sentencing.

Atty Cousins states appearances.

The Court has received the PSI and had it forwarded it to the parties.
Atty Cousins received a copy.
The Court addresses one correction on page 3, DOC copy is to be corrected to reflect intentional homicide as it reflects on the front page of the PSI.
Atty Otis received a copy as well, reviewed the report with his client, states three clarifications for the record.

Atty Otis states there is no reason why his client should not be sentenced today.
Atty Otis has one witness to present and the victim would like to make a statement.

1:37 PM Steven Pray is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Otis. 
Mr. Pray makes statement.
1:49 PM Cross-examination by Atty Cousins.

Atty Otis has no further witnesses.

State has complied with victim notification statutes.
Victim would like to make a statement.
Atty Cousins received three victim impact statements, hands to Court for review.

Court received a letter from A.P. 
Parties did receive a copy of the letter.

Court also received a letter from R.P.
Parties also receive a copy of the letter.

1:52 PM Court takes a moment to review the three victim impact statements.

Atty Cousins states that there are family members of the victim present in the courtroom, and they wish that the statements be read outloud.

1:53 PM Atty Cousins reads the statements for the record.

1:57 PM Jennifer Pray addresses the Court.

There are no further statements.

2:04 PM Atty Cousins addresses the Court prior to sentencing, recommends eligibility of parole after 40 years.

2:30 PM Atty Otis addresses the Court prior to sentencing, recommends eligibility for extended supervision at 20 years.

2:51 PM Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.

2:51 PM Court reviewed the pre-sentencing investigation, found it thoughtful, thorough and complete.
Court addresses the parties, reviews facts of the case, reviews extended supervision options.
Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing such as gravity of offense and character/health of Defendant.

BY THE COURT:
Initial Confinement for Life
Eligible for Petitioning for Extended Supervision after serving 20 Years 
378 Days Jail Credit
Conditions:
Pay Restitution of $217.00 to Julia Buchberger
Pay Restitution of $1,313.40 to Elizabeth Bonnstetter-Kluck
Court grants the State 30 days for any further restitution request
Do not have any contact with the biological family of Christopher Bonnstetter unless they consent to such contact and the social worker allows
If there is any wish for victim offender couseling, Court will admit that
Comply with any assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Department of Corrections and their use of the Compas assessment
Sign releases of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacies and/or treatment that Defendant receives, to the agent
Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge 
If released, set up a payment plan
Provide DNA for testing
Pay DNA Surcharge
Pay Court Costs
Pay Domestic Abuse Surcharge of $100
Payments for court costs are to come out of prison account at the rate of 25%

Written explanation of Determinate Life Sentence is given to the Defendant.
Court thanks the family for appearing.

3:19 PM Court is in recess.
Sentencing hearing on June 9, 2015 at 01:30 pm.
Juror notes with partial transcript
from the Jury

Defendant Andrew S. Pray in court with attorney Nathan Otis and Attorney Jessa Nicholson.  Cass W Cousins and Louis Molepske, Jr. appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

8:08 AM Court calls case.
Atty Cousins states appearances.

Defense moved for a mistrial when Court last broke. This is the opportunity for parties to discuss this issue at this time.

Both parties are prepared to proceed.

Atty Otis addresses the Court regarding motion for mistrial.

Atty Cousins addresses the Court, this is a harmless error.

Court addresses the parties. Court was concerned when Court heard the prosecutors statements.  Court asked the Court Reporter to make a partial transcript. 

Both parties received this partial transcript.

Court reviews the partial transcript for the record. Court reviews the objection, violation of the golden rule. 

BY THE COURT:
Court finds statement was not completed, that context of remaining comments of prosecutor goes to intent of the will of force, legitimate grounds.  Court cannot find that the statement affected the trial with unfairness. Court denies motion for mistrial.

Atty Otis addresses the Court, an additional matter, burden of proof. 

Atty Cousins addresses the Court regarding changing the pattern of jury instructions, not necessary.  
Atty Otis replies, regarding the proper burden.

Court addresses the parties regarding burden. 

Atty Otis presents to the Court the proposed jury instruction phrase, copy given to Prosecutor.   

Court takes a moment to review the Avila case. 192 Wis 2nd 870 at 887.

Court has reviewed the case that was cited, addresses the parties.

Atty Otis addresses the Court.
Atty Cousins replies.

BY THE COURT:
Court will include a supplemental instruction, states instruction for the record.

Court will redraft 465, will take about 5 minutes.

8:39 AM Court is in recess.

8:48 AM Court is back in session, same appearances.

Court has amended instruction 465 to include the language that was addressed.
Atty Otis addresses the Court, points out a typo.
Atty Cousins states that language is satisfactory.

8:49 AM Court takes a moment to correct typo.

8:54 AM Jurors enter the courtroom. All 13 members are present.
Court states appearances.
Court welcomes jurors.

8:55 AM Court gives closing instructions at this time. Court reads the four verdict forms.

9:00 AM Juror #1417 is excused.
Clerk administers Oath of Officers to the Bailiffs.

9:01 AM Jurors are excused for deliberations.

Atty Cousins addresses the Court regarding exhibits.
Court replies.

9:02 AM Court is in recess.  

10:38 AM Court is back on the record, outside of presence of jury.
Atty Cousins states appearances.

The Court has received a note from the foreperson requesting all photos from the trial.  Court looked at the file, appears that the  #3 through #28, #30 through #33,  and #40.

State does not object.
Atty Otis does not object.

BY THE COURT:
Court will allow the photographic exhibits be taken back to the jury room.
#3-#28, #30-#33, and #40

Bailiff takes the exhibits to the jury room.
Court will retain the jurors note in the file.

10:42 AM Court is in recess.

2:26 PM All twelve jurors are escorted back into the courtroom.
2:28 PM Court is back in session.
Atty Cousins states appearances.
Court makes statements 
Court received a request during the lunch hour from two Jurors and the Court did allow it.
Foreperson provides Verdict to the Bailiff.
Court reads the Verdict.

Defendant is found GUILTY  of 1st Degree Intentional Homicide 

Defense requests Jury be polled.
Court polls the Jury.
All twelve Jurors answer.

2:33 PM Court thanks the Jurors for their service.
Jurors are excused.

2:34 PM Atty Cousins moves Judgment be entered on the Verdict.

BY THE COURT:
Court grants motion for Judgment on the Verdict.
Court orders Judgment of Guilty be entered.
Bond is revoked and Defendant is remanded to the Sheriffs custody.
Court orders Exhibit #37 (Medical Records) be sealed.

Sentencing is set for 1:30pm on June 9, 2015
PSI will be ordered. (Off the record)
All Exhibits accounted for.

the testimony of the parties.  Court does not find that the testimony has been unusually quiet and has not had this problem before. 
Atty Cousins indicates it has been soft but hes heard everyone. 
Atty Nicholson has not had trouble hearing anyone.  Asks if the juror that wrote the note is the same as the juror who wrote the note earlier this morning. 
Court believes it is not the same juror. 
Atty Nicholson makes additional statements to the Court. 
Neither party are requesting individual voir dire of the jury.
Atty Nicholson makes additional requests. 
Court will question the jury. 

1:51 p.m .  Jurors are escorted to the Courtroom. 
Court questions the jury regarding ability to hear testimony.  No one responds. 
Court advises jury to raise their hands if they do have any trouble hearing. 

1:55 p.m.  Defense rests.   State will not be calling any rebuttal witnesses. 
Court informs the Jury that evidentiary portion has been completed.  Parties will need some time to finalize the jury instructions. 
1:56 p.m . Jurors are escorted from the courtroom. 

1:58 p.m.  Court and parties discuss the jury instructions in chambers.  Court takes a recess. 

2:17 p.m.  Court is back in session outside the presence of the jury. 
Appearances remain the same. 
Parties have been provided with the final jury instruction forms.  
There are no corrections.  Both parties are satisfied. 
Atty Nicholson renews the motion to dismiss. 
BY THE COURT:  Motion is denied. 
Court addresses the issue of the alternate juror. 
Parties agree to choose the alternate at random. 

2:20 p.m.  Jurors are escorted to the Courtroom. 
2:21 p.m.  Court administers instructions to the jury. 
2:44 p.m.  Atty Cousins makes closing arguments to the Court. 
3:18 p.m.  Atty Otis makes closing arguments to the Court. 
3:53 p.m.  Atty Cousins makes rebuttal arguments to the Court. 
4:06 p.m.  Sidebar is conducted. 

4:07 p.m.  Court advises jurors they are not to discuss the case with anyone. 
Jurors are excused for the day.  They are advised to be present by 8:30 a.m. 

4:09 p.m.  Atty Otis moves for a mistrial.  Makes arguments in support of the motion. 
Atty Cousins makes arguments in opposition to the motion. 

BY THE COURT:  Court can give a corrective instruction.  Court needs to give the matter.  At this point the Court is not inclined to give a mistrial.  Does believe it 
was a violation of the motion in limine ruling.  If parties wish to address further, the matter will be heard at 8:00 a.m.  

Court notes duplication in the jury instruction which has been removed from the jury instructions.  
Neither parties object. 

4:13 p.m.  Court is in recess until 8:00 a.m.

Defendant Andrew S. Pray in court with attorney Nathan Otis and Attorney Jessa Nicholson.  Cass W Cousins and Louis Molepske, Jr. appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

8:41 a.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Cousins states the appearances.
Atty Cousins indicates that the state will rest and will still need to move into evidence Exhibits #1 & #2 and to discuss the Motion in Limine.
Atty Nicholson makes statements regarding the Colique (?) 
Court questions the defendant in regards to if he will testify or not.
Defendant indicates that he will be testifying. 
Court questions Atty Otis.
Court finds that the defendant is making  his decision knowingly, intelligently and voluntary to testify; Defendants counsel stipulate to this.  
Court goes through the Motion in Limine; Atty Cousins makes statements regarding the Motion in Limine and the expert witness testifying after defendant has testified.   State is questioning the need for the expert testimony at this time.  
8:47 a.m.   Atty Otis makes statements regarding the testimony of Dr Jurek (expert witness). 
Court questions when Dr Jurek will testify and this will be after the defendant testifies.
Court makes statements and indicates that the testimony of Dr Jurek is relevant and will allow the testimony of Dr Jurek.
8:50 a.m.  Atty Cousins will rest for the State;  Atty Cousins move both Exhibits #1 & #2 into evidence; no objection for Exhibit #1 but there is an objection to Exhibit #2.   Exhibit #1 is Received by the Court.  Exhibit #2 is denied admission into evidence by the Court.
8:52 a.m.  Atty Nicholson moves for an acquittal.
Motion for Acquittal is denied;  Court  makes statements in regards to the status of the case.
8:57 a.m.   All 13 Jurors have returned to the Courtroom.  
Court apologizes for the late start due to an equipment malfunction and the appreciation of the Jurors being here on time.
The State rests per Atty Cousins.
8:59 a.m.  R. Pumper is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Otis.
Witness identifies the defendant.   Record reflects that the witness has identified the defendant. 
9:01 a.m.   Cross examination by Atty Cousins.
9:06 a.m.   No re-direct by Atty Otis.
Witness is excused.
9:06 a.m.  A. Pray is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Otis.
9:21 a.m.  Atty Cousins interrupts and indicates that one of the Jurors may have a hearing issue. Bailiff retrieves a hearing device for the Juror.   This is Juror #1393.
9:24 a.m.  Atty Otis continues with his direct examination.
9:46 a.m.  Atty Cousins objects to form of question; overruled.
9:47 a.m.  Atty Cousins objects to form of question; overruled.
9:48 a.m.   Jurors exit the courtroom.
Court questions if there is anything they would like to put on the record.
Atty Cousins makes a statement regarding an impeachment.
Atty Otis makes a statement regarding the impeachment.
Atty Cousins makes further statements.
Atty Otis makes further statements.
Court agrees with the defense counsel.   Court informs Atty Cousins to review this during the recess.
9:52 a.m.  Court is in recess.
10:07 a.m.  Court is back in session.
Appearances remain as they were prior to the recess.
Court questions if either party would like to put information on the record.
Atty Cousins makes statements in regards to the information he reviewed during the recess regarding an impeachment and provides specific case law.
Court questions Atty Cousins what he plans on presenting to the Court.
Atty Cousins makes statements.
10:10 a.m.  Atty Otis makes statements in regards to what Atty Cousins has stated on the record regarding the impeachment.
Court makes comment on the Statute referenced by Atty Otis; State is authorized by Statute to present character testimony and states this on the record. 
The witness on the stand is not the one that had given an opinion regarding the case and the conduct and is not admissible at this time.  The State may present their own evidence.
10:14 a.m.  Neither party has anything further to put on the record prior to the return of the Jurors.
10:15 a.m.  The record indicates that the Jurors have now returned to the courtroom.
Cross examination by Atty Cousins.
10:21 a.m.  Atty Otis objects to the form of the question; overruled.
10:24 a.m.  Atty Otis objects due to relevance of question; overruled.
10:38 a.m.  Court informs the defendant to speak into the microphone.
10:48 a.m.  Re-direct by Atty Otis.
10:55 a.m.  Atty Cousins objects; overruled.
10:56 a.m.  Re-cross by Atty Cousins.
10:57 a.m.  Defendant informed again to speak into the microphone.
10:58 a.m.  Counsel has no further questions.
Attorneys approach for a sidebar.
Court received a note from one of the Jurors indicating that they had a difficult time hearing the defendant.  
Court asks the Jurors if they were not able to hear the testimony in its totality;
No hands are raised.   Court thanks the Jurors for bringing this to the attention of the Court.
11:00 a.m.  Witness is excused.
11:02 a.m.  Exhibits #39-#41 are marked for Atty Otis.
11:01 a.m.  Dr Anthony Jurek is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Otis.
11:03 a.m.  Atty Otis references Exhibit #39.
Atty Otis moves Exhibit #39 into evidence; no objection by Atty Cousins. Received by the Court.
11:25 a.m.  Atty Otis references Exhibit #40 and #41.
Atty Otis would like to publish Exhibit #40 & #41 as demonstrative evidence.  
Court informs Atty Otis needs to be offered prior to publishing.
Atty Cousins objects indicating that this testimony is unnecessary.
Atty Otis offers Exhibits #40 & #41 to the Court as Demonstrative Evidence only.  Accepted by the Court as demonstrative exhibit/evidence.
Atty Otis publishes photos to the Courtroom/Jurors by an overhead projector.
11:32 a.m.  Atty Cousins objects to relevancy of question; overruled.
11:33 a.m.  Atty Cousins objects as speculative question; sustained as to form of question.
11:46 a.m.  Exhibit #42 is marked for Atty Cousins.
Cross examination by Atty Cousins.
Atty Cousins references Exhibit #42.
Atty Cousins moves Exhibit #42 into evidence; Atty Otis objects as to the Exhibit being hearsay.  Court will receive Exhibit #42 at this time.
11:56 a.m.  Atty Otis objects to the relevance of question; sustained.
11:57 a.m.  Atty Cousins references exhibit #42, page 20 & 30.
11:58 a.m.  Atty Otis objects to the relevance of the question; sustained on foundation.  
Atty Otis once again objects and requests to approach the bench (sidebar).
12:01 p.m.  Atty Cousins withdraws his last question.
12:03 p.m.  Atty Otis objects to the question as being asked/answered; sustained.   Second objection by  Atty Otis to relevance; sustained.
Re-direct by Atty Otis.
12:07 p.m.  Lunch break will be until 1:30 p.m.
Jurors exit the courtroom and the record reflects this.
Court indicates that there was a sidebar regarding questioning by the State.
Court questions if there are any further issues on the matter discussed at the sidebar.  Neither party has anything further.
Atty Nicholson makes statement regarding the Juror that had the hearing issue.  Atty Nicholson would request that Juror #1393 become the second alternate.

Court makes statements in regards to this and will take this information into consideration.
12:11 p.m.   Atty Nicholson indicates that the defense intends to rest unless the State has any rebuttal witnesses.
12:12 p.m.  Court will take a brief moment to go through the Jury Instructions with Counsel and does so on the record.
12:16 p.m.  Court questions if the parties had an opportunity to review the language.   Atty Nicholson makes comment.
Atty Cousins has no comment.
12:17 p.m.  Atty Nicholson makes further statements regarding a bracketed paragraph in the Jury Instructions 1018; Atty Cousins has no objection.  Atty Nicholson has no objection to changing the language (one word changed).  This is stated on the record.
Court questions if there is anything further on 1018.  
12:19 p.m.  Court continues the review of the Jury Instructions.
12:21 p.m.  Atty Nicholson has some additional requests to the Jury Instructions.
Court continues the review of the Jury Instructions.
12:29 p.m.  Court questions the parties if the have had the opportunity to review the verdict forms.
Counsel on both sides have  had the opportunity to review the verdict forms.
Atty Nicholson makes statements.
Court responds to the request of Atty Nicholson.
Counsel has nothing else for the record.
Defense  counsel will be resting and the State does not have any rebuttal witnesses for this afternoon.
Atty Otis questions the procedure of doing Jury Instructions and then doing closing arguments.
12:33 p.m.  Court is in recess and all parties need to be back by 1:30 p.m. 
Clerk has accounted for all exhibits.
1:40 p.m.  Court calls the case. 
Appearances remain the same as this morning. 
Atty Nicholson makes statements regarding a rebuttal witness and makes arguments for her objection. 
Atty Cousins makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Cousins. 
Atty Nicholson makes additional arguments. 
Atty Cousins makes additional arguments.  Makes offer of proof to the Court. 
Atty Nicholson makes arguments. 
BY THE COURT:  Court is concerned there is not sufficient foundation laid.  Court will not allow that testimony for lack of foundation and Court does not want to turn this into a mini trial. The 3 week period is not sufficient to form an appropriate opinion. 

Court notes he has received a note from the jury re: witnesses speaking into the microphone.  Court is concerned there is the ongoing issue with the jury hearing

Exhibits #3 thru #28 are marked on behalf of the plaintiff prior to Court.
Defendant Andrew S. Pray in court with attorney Nathan Otis and attorney Jessa Nicholson. Attorney Cass W Cousins and attorney Louis Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
8:20 a.m.  Court calls the case. 
Atty Cousins states the appearances. 
Atty Otis objects to Exhibits #10 thru #15.  Makes arguments to the Court regarding his objections.  
Atty Cousins makes arguments.  Offers proof for Exhibits #10 - #15.
Court questions Atty Cousins re: #11 - #13.
Atty Cousins responds. 
Atty Otis makes additional arguments. 

BY THE COURT:  Court has reviewed exhibits #10 thru #15.  Court finds that they are relevant and Court does not believe that undue prejudice outweighs the probative value and the Court will allow all of these photographs objected to to be presented to the jury.  Subject to any other testimony that may affect the courts decision.  

8:41 a.m.  Atty Cousins requests a few minute break. 
8:44 a.m.  Atty Cousins makes statements.  The doctor he was going to testify at 11:00 this morning he had an emergency with a patient and will be calling him this afternoon instead.  
8:46 a.m.  Jurors are escorted to the Courtroom. 

8:47 a.m.  Officer M. Tracy is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
Witness identifies the defendant. 
Atty Otis stipulates to identification. 
8:51 a.m.  Sidebar is conducted. 
8:53 a.m.  Direct exam continues. 
8:54 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Otis. Testimony has concluded.

8:54 a.m.  Sgt. K. Sorenson is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
9:06 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Otis. 
9:08 a.m.  Testimony has concluded. 

9:09 a.m.  Officer B. Thauer is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
Witness identifies the defendant. 
Atty Otis stipulates to identification. 
Exhibits #3 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibit #3.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibit #3 is received. 
Exhibit #3 is published to the jury. 
Exhibits #4 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibit #4.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibit #4 is admitted. 
Exhibit #4 is published to the jury. 
Exhibits #5 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibit #5.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibit #5 is admitted. 
Exhibit #5 is published to the jury. 
Exhibits #6 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibit #6.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibit #6 is admitted. 
Exhibit #6 is published to the jury. 
9:30 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Otis. 
9:34 a.m.  Re-direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
9:35 a.m.  Re-cross exam by Atty Otis. 
9:36 a.m.  Testimony has concluded. 

9:36 a.m.  Det. B. Noel is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
Exhibit #16, 17 are referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibit #16 & #17.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibits #16 & #17 are admitted. 
Exhibits #18, #20,# 21, #19 are referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibits #18 thru #21.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibits #18 thru #21 are admitted and published. 
Exhibit #22 is referred to during testimony.
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibits #18 thru #21.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT: Exhibits #21 and #22 are admitted and published.
Exhibits #23 & #24 are referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibits #23 & #24.  No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibits #23 & #24 are admitted and published. 
Exhibit #25, 26, 27 are referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibits #25, 26 & 27. No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #28 Are admitted and published. 
Exhibit #28 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Cousins moves for the admission of Exhibits #28. No objection by Atty Otis. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibits #28 is admitted.
Exhibit #29 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff. 
10:01 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Otis. 
Exhibits #30, 31, 32 & 33 are marked on behalf of the defendant. 
Atty Otis moves for the admission of Exhibits #30, 31, 32 & 33.  No objection by Atty Cousins. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibits ##30, 31, 32 & 33 are admitted and published. 
10:08 a.m.  Re-direct exam by Atty Cousins. 
10:09 a.m.  Sidebar is conducted. 
10:10 a.m.  Jurors are escorted from the Courtroom.  

10:11 a.m.  Court is in session outside the presence of the jury. 
Atty Cousins makes statements re: cross exam. 
Atty Otis makes arguments to the Court.  Files with the Court a transcript of defendants statement. 
Court reviews the file.  Does not see that the transcript is part of the file.  Asks that the statement be marked as an exhibit. 
Exhibit #34 is marked on behalf of the defendant.  Neither party objects to the admission.

State has no objection to granting each of the 4 motions.

Atty Cousins addresses the Court.

BY THE COURT:

Remaining motion is the State's Motion in Limine to exclude expert testimony.

Court replies.

Atty Otis addresses the Court.
